column2: What is GRAD 800?
column3: Continuing graduate students who are not enrolled for course credits, thesis credits, Doctoral Research (999), or GRAD 900 Master’s Continuing Research (GRAD 900) are not in residence, and are not exempt from the continuous enrollment policy, are required to register for GRAD 800 Continuing Enrollment each semester of the academic year (or each summer for students in M.S.T programs).

column2: How do I sibmity my committee?

column2: What is the difference between an IA and an IC grade?
column3: IA grades are assigned with the approval of the instructor for excused unfinished work only. "IA" indicates an Incomplete in continuing multi-semester work (e.g., thesis/doctoral research); earlier IA terms remain on the transcript, and only the final completed term receives CR when applicable.
column4: ["- grading (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Question%3A%20What%20is%20the%20difference%20between%20an%20IA%20and%20an%20IC%20grade%3F)", "- grading (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Question%3A%20What%E2%80%99s%20the%20difference%20between%20IA%20and%20IC%20grades%20for%20graduate%20students%3F)", "- grading (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Question%3A%20What%20is%20an%20IA%20grade%3F)", "- grading (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Question%3A%20What%20does%20an%20AF%20grade%20mean%3F)", "- grading (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Question%3A%20What%20does%20an%20AU%20grade%20mean%3F)", "- grading (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)", "- grading (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)"]

column2: What GPA do graduate students need to be eligible for graduation?
column3: A cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher is required to be eligible for graduation.
column4: ["- Academic Standards Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/)"]

column2: What is the minimum grade for earning graduate credit?
column3: Graduate credit is granted only for courses completed with a grade of B- or higher; some programs set stricter requirements.
column4: ["- Academic Standards Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/)"]

column2: How many credits below B- lead to dismissal from the Graduate School?
column3: Receiving grades below B- in 9 or more credits results in dismissal from the Graduate School.
column4: ["- Academic Standards Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/)"]

column2: What happens if an accelerated master’s student earns below B- in a graduate course while in dual status?
column3: They may be dismissed and have their Graduate School admission withdrawn.
column4: ["- Academic Standards Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/)"]

column2: How many chances do master’s or Ed.S. students get to pass their final exam?
column3: They have a maximum of two opportunities to successfully complete final examinations.
column4: ["- Academic Standards Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/)"]

column2: How many chances do Ph.D. students get to pass qualifying or final exams?
column3: Doctoral students have a maximum of two opportunities to pass qualifying or final examinations.
column4: ["- Academic Standards Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/)"]

column2: What must conditionally admitted graduate students do to remain in the Graduate School?
column3: They must meet the conditions stated in their admission letter.
column4: ["- Academic Standards Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/)"]

column2: Can programs set stricter academic standards than the Graduate School?
column3: Yes. Programs may set stricter standards and may dismiss students for fewer than 9 credits below B- or for inadequate progress.
column4: ["- Academic Standards Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/)"]

column2: What is the deadline to appeal a dismissal decision?
column3: A student must submit an appeal within ten business days of the dismissal notification.
column4: ["- Academic Standards Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/)"]

column2: Who recommends and who decides a dismissal for lack of academic progress?
column3: The department chair or graduate program coordinator, upon faculty committee recommendation, may recommend dismissal; the associate dean of the Graduate School acts on the recommendation.
column4: ["- Academic Standards Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/)"]

column2: How many graduate credits are required for a master’s degree at UNH?
column3: A minimum of 30 graduate credits is required for all master's degrees. Many programs require substantially more than the minimum 30 credits. Individual program requirements are outlined in the program descriptions of this catalog.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: Can 700-level courses count for graduate credit?
column3: In rare cases, up to 12 credits at the 700 level from outside the student’s program may count with an approved petition, and they must be taken for a letter grade.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: Is a capstone required for master’s programs?
column3: The capstone is required for all master’s degrees, including coursework, performance, internship, portfolio, exam, research project, or thesis.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Question%3A%20Is%20a%20capstone%20required%20for%20master%E2%80%99s%20programs%3F)", "- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Question%3A%20How%20many%20graduate%20credits%20are%20required%20for%20a%20master%E2%80%99s%20degree%20at%20UNH%3F)", "- Cybersecurity Engineering Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/computing/cybersecurity-engineering-ms/#:~:text=Question%3A%20Does%20the%20Cybersecurity%20Engineering%20%28M.S.%29%20requirements%20page%20describe%20a%20capstone%20or%20culminating%20experience%3F)", "- Biotechnology Industrial Biomedical Sciences Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/biotechnology/biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms/#:~:text=Question%3A%20When%20can%20students%20in%20the%20Biotechnology%3A%20Industrial%20and%20Biomedical%20Sciences%20%28M.S.%29%20program%20begin%20their%20capstone%20experience%3F)", "- Biotechnology Industrial Biomedical Sciences Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/biotechnology/biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms/#:~:text=Question%3A%20What%20is%20the%20credit%20range%20for%20the%20Capstone%20Experience%20in%20the%20Biotechnology%3A%20Industrial%20and%20Biomedical%20Sciences%20%28M.S.%29%20program%3F)", "- Biotechnology Industrial Biomedical Sciences Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/biotechnology/biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms/#requirementstext)"]

column2: What are the residency requirements for the Ph.D.?
column3: At least three academic years of graduate study are required, with at least one full academic year in residence at UNH.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: What is Doctoral Research (999) and when must Ph.D. students register for it?
column3: At least two semesters of 999 are required. After candidacy, Ph.D. students must register for 999 each semester of the academic year; it is 0 credits but confers full-time status.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: When is a Ph.D. student advanced to candidacy and what form is required?
column3: After passing the qualifying exam, meeting program proficiency requirements, declaring a dissertation topic, and forming the doctoral committee; students should file the Advancement to Candidacy form as soon as requirements are met.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: What are the key rules for the Accelerated Master’s program?
column3: Typically requires a 3.20 GPA; students may take up to 12 credits of 800-level courses before finishing the bachelor’s; with approval, up to 8 credits may count toward a graduate certificate; credits can count toward both bachelor’s and master’s as approved.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: What does an AF grade mean?
column3: AF (Administrative F) is assigned for failure to drop or complete a course and counts the same as an F.
column4: ["- Grading Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)"]

column2: When is a CR grade used?
column3: CR (Credit) is used for successful completion of designated Credit/Fail courses such as thesis/dissertation and approved seminars.
column4: ["- Grading Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)"]

column2: What does an AU grade mean?
column3: AU indicates an approved audit; no credit is earned.
column4: ["- Grading Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)"]

column2: How does an Incomplete (IC) work for graduate courses?
column3: An IC is allowed for excused unfinished work with instructor approval; work must be finished by the agreed date, no later than the last day of classes in the next semester for 800/900-level courses (earlier mid-semester deadline for 400–700). Extensions require a petition and usually do not exceed one year.
column4: ["- Grading Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)"]

column2: What does NR mean on a graduate record?
column3: NR means Not Resolved due to a pending academic integrity allegation.
column4: ["- Grading Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)"]

column2: What is the policy on course withdrawal (W) and its impact?
column3: With an approved petition during the withdrawal period, a W is recorded; failing to withdraw results in an AF. Not attending does not count as withdrawal. Deadlines are on the Academic Calendar.
column4: ["- Grading Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)"]

column2: What happens when a graduate course is repeated?
column3: Only the most recent grade counts in the GPA and only the most recent credit counts toward credits earned. A course may be repeated only once, and only repeats at UNH change the GPA. Failing a required course twice is grounds for dismissal.
column4: ["- Grading Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)"]

column2: How many times per year are graduate degrees conferred at UNH?
column3: Three times: September 1, December 31, and May (date varies).
column4: ["- Graduation Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/)"]

column2: Do I have to file an intent to graduate?
column3: Yes. Students must file an intent-to-graduate via Webcat by the deadline on the UNH Academic Calendar; otherwise the degree will not be awarded.
column4: ["- Graduation Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/)"]

column2: What must be completed before the degree conferral date?
column3: All degree requirements and coursework must be completed before the conferral date, and the cumulative GPA must be at least 3.0.
column4: ["- Graduation Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/)"]

column2: When is the annual commencement ceremony?
column3: Commencement is held in May.
column4: ["- Graduation Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/)"]

column2: Who can participate in the May commencement ceremony?
column3: Doctoral, master’s, Ed.S., and certificate students who earned degrees the previous September or December are invited; master’s, Ed.S., and certificate students who expect to complete in May or at the end of the summer term (September) are eligible to participate.
column4: ["- Graduation Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/)"]

column2: What must doctoral students do to participate in the May ceremony?
column3: Doctoral students must complete all degree requirements by the published May deadlines to participate.
column4: ["- Graduation Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/)"]

column2: Do I need to register to attend commencement?
column3: Yes. All graduate students who intend to participate must register via the Commencement Office.
column4: ["- Graduation Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/)"]

column2: Where can I find the intent-to-graduate deadlines?
column3: On the UNH Academic Calendar.
column4: ["- Graduation Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/)"]

column2: Where can I read more about the graduation process?
column3: On the Graduate School’s website; the page links to it for more information.
column4: ["- Graduation Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/)"]

column2: Who issues official transcripts and what is required before receiving a diploma?
column3: The Registrar maintains official records and partners with Parchment for online ordering. All University accounts must be satisfied before a diploma is issued.
column4: ["- Graduation Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/)"]

column2: What is an IA grade?
column3: IA Grades: "IA" indicates "incomplete" in thesis credit, doctoral research, or other continuing courses of more than one semester. The grade earned will replace the "IA" once the work has been completed. In the case of doctoral research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR". Prior semester "IA" grades will remain on the official transcript.
column4: ["- Grading Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)"]

column2: Can I do a dual degree?
column3: Dual Degrees The Graduate School allows UNH students to pursue two degrees at UNH and count credits toward both degrees under the circumstances detailed below. Such credit will be granted only for graded coursework completed with a grade of "B-" or higher. Application of such credit toward a student’s program for a second degree is subject to departmental recommendation and approval by the Graduate School. Dual degrees should be interpreted to include separate majors within the same degree, or a combination of two different degrees. Students will receive separate diplomas for each degree program. Note: Dual degrees will NOT be awarded retroactively.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: Can I appeal a dismissal?
column3: Appeals Process To appeal a dismissal decision, a student must submit a letter and any supporting documents to the program chairperson and the dean of the Graduate School within ten (10) business days of the dismissal notification. The appeal should provide specific evidence, context, or mitigating factors that the student believes should be considered in reviewing the decision. The appeal should refer specifically to the grounds of the original decision in making this appeal and provide reference to relevant policy where applicable. Generally, dismissed students will not be able to continue in classes pending the outcome of the appeal, but the program chairperson may make a final decision regarding if the student can continue in the program pending the appellate review or continue with conditions.
column4: ["- Academic Standards Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/)"]

column2: How do I reach degree candidacy?
column3: Ph.D. Candidacy A Ph.D. student is advanced to candidacy for the degree by the dean of the Graduate School upon recommendation of the graduate program coordinator after the student has passed the qualifying examination, met the language or proficiency requirements as are deemed desirable by the student’s program, declared a topic for dissertation research, and fully formed their doctoral dissertation committee. *Students are expected to file an Advancement to Candidacy form with the Graduate School as soon as possible after all of the requirements for candidacy have been met.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: How long do I have to complete my master’s degree?
column3: Master’s Time Limit All graduate work for any master’s degree must normally be completed within four years from the date of matriculation (enrollment following admission) in the program. Progress toward the degree will be carefully monitored by the advisor and the Graduate School to ensure that adequate advancement is made toward the completion of the program and that any deficiencies noted at the time of admission are removed. Students failing to make adequate advancement toward completion of the program are subject to dismissal in advance of the four-year time limit. Extensions to the four-year time limit will be considered on a case-by-case basis. Years on leave do not count toward the time limit.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: Do I need RCR training?
column3: RESPONSIBLE CONDUCT OF RESEARCH As a land-grant institution, the University of New Hampshire (UNH) is accountable to New Hampshire residents and to the University community to ensure the ethical and safe conduct of research and scholarly activity. As an institution of higher education that prides itself on extensive research endeavors and the involvement of undergraduates and graduate students in research projects, UNH has an obligation to teach and actively promote integrity in research and scholarship. To fulfill its obligations, UNH has embarked on a program on the responsible conduct of research and scholarly activity (RCR) to: Raise the consciousness of faculty, staff, and students regarding the ethical and responsible conduct of research and scholarly activity Establish a knowledge base that defines normative and/or professional behavior to assist faculty, staff, and students in making ethical and responsible decisions in the conduct of research and scholarly activity Foster an institutional culture of integrity in research and scholarly activity. To support these efforts, the Graduate Council has mandated that all incoming Ph.D. students complete RCR training approved by the Graduate School by the end of their first semester. For more information, visit the RCR website.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements)"]

column2: What is a non-terminal degree?
column3: Non-Terminal Master’s Degrees Ph.D. students, with the approval of their department, may petition to earn a non-terminal master’s degree while completing the Ph.D. degree. Students must complete the master’s degree requirements for their particular program as noted in the Graduate Catalog. Petitions should be submitted to the Graduate School at the start of the semester in which graduation is desired.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements)"]

column2: How many thesis credits do I need to complete for my program?
column3: Thesis Credit During their degree program, a student completing a thesis must enroll in at least 6 but no more than 10 thesis credits. Students are advised to review their program’s degree requirements as the exact number of required thesis credits within each program can vary. The exact number of thesis credits that are required for each degree will be determined by the faculty of the individual programs. Students are not eligible to receive credit for any more than the maximum number of thesis credits required by the degree and are expected to monitor their registration to ensure that they do not exceed the maximum. No thesis credit shall be given until the completed thesis has been approved by the thesis committee and accepted by the Graduate School. Satisfactory acceptance of the thesis will be recorded with a grade of (CR).
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: Where do I file an intent to graduate?
column3: Degree Conferral Graduate degrees are conferred three times per year (September 1, December 31, and May (date varies)). All students MUST file an intent-to-graduate through Webcat by the appropriate deadline specified on the UNH Academic Calendar. Students who do not file an intent-to-graduate will not have their degree awarded. More information on this process is available on the Graduate School’s website.
column4: ["- Graduation Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/)"]

column2: What is the deadline to file an intent to graduate?
column3: Degree Conferral Graduate degrees are conferred three times per year (September 1, December 31, and May (date varies)). All students MUST file an intent-to-graduate through Webcat by the appropriate deadline specified on the UNH Academic Calendar. Students who do not file an intent-to-graduate will not have their degree awarded. More information on this process is available on the Graduate School’s website.
column4: ["- Graduation Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/)"]

column2: How do I apply to grad school?
column3: Applying for Admission Persons holding a baccalaureate degree from an accredited college or university may apply for admission to the Graduate School. Admission is both limited and competitive and is based solely upon academic qualifications and potential of the individual. All application materials become part of the permanent records of the University of New Hampshire and will not be returned. Access to this material is limited under the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act of 1974. Applicants who are not admitted, or who are admitted and do not register in the Graduate School, do not have access to their application files. Materials received as part of the application process will not be duplicated for personal use by the applicant or forwarded to a third party. Materials received from applicants who do not complete their application, who are not admitted, or who are admitted and do not register are held for one year before being destroyed. Application procedures, including deadlines and program-specific requirements, are available at the Graduate School website: http://www.gradschool.unh.edu.
column4: ["- Admissions Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/admissions/)"]

column2: What is the application deadline?
column3: Dates can vary by year and program. For the most current official dates (start/end of term, add/drop, holidays, finals, etc.), please see the Registrar’s Academic Calendar: https://www.unh.edu/registrar/registration-resources/calendars-important-deadlines

column2: Can I take courses without applying?
column3: Non-Degree Students www.unh.edu/continuingeducation/graduate-coursework Individuals holding a bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university may register for graduate courses through The Office of Continuing Education. These individuals are designated as "non-degree students." Non-degree students are not required to file an application for admission to the Graduate School and are not candidates for a graduate degree. Non-degree students may register for a maximum of 8 credits per semester. Registering for 9 or more credits requires special permission. Please note special permission is not required to exceed the 8 credit limit during the summer.
column4: ["- Admissions Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/admissions/)"]

column2: What is the Accelerated Master’s program?
column3: Accelerated Master’s Program (University of New Hampshire Seniors) gradschool.unh.edu/academics/accelerated-masters-program Qualified senior students at the University of New Hampshire may apply early and be admitted to the Graduate School prior to completing their bachelor’s degree provided they have followed normal application procedures and have been admitted for the semester in which they wish to enroll in courses for dual credit (the first semester of their senior year). A 3.20 cumulative grade-point average is normally required to be considered for admission to the accelerated master’s program, though some departments may have higher GPA requirements. Seniors who have been admitted to an approved program under the accelerated master’s program and have completed 90 undergraduate credits may register for a maximum of 12 credits of 800-level courses prior to completing their bachelor’s degree. Such courses may, upon recommendation of the department and approval of the Graduate School, count toward both a bachelor’s and master’s degree (12 credit maximum) or graduate certificate program (8 credit maximum).
column4: ["- Admissions Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/admissions/)"]

column2: Can I defer my admission?
column3: Deferred Admission Applicants who cannot enroll in the term for which admission was offered may request to have their admission deferred for up to one year. Students who request a deferral, and who are not currently active in another degree program, are responsible for dropping any courses they may be currently enrolled in at the time they request the deferral. Such requests must be in writing and will be considered only once. Because enrollments are limited and competition for admission may vary from year to year, such requests may not be granted. Applicants who have received approved deferment of their admission cannot register for graduate coursework at the University during the period of deferment.
column4: ["- Admissions Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/admissions/)"]

column2: Is there housing available?
column3: The UNH Graduate Catalog provides housing for students aged 21 and older, including graduate and international students. Details are listed on the UNH Housing website under Graduate Housing. Key Points: Graduate housing at Babcock Hall; 21+ community with mix of students; Info on UNH housing site  Campus Life Information No.

column2: Does UNH offer student health insurance?
column3: Health Insurance University policy requires full-time degree students that are enrolled in at least one in-person course to have health insurance as a condition of enrollment. Some students have the option of waiving this requirement if they present proof of adequate coverage; alternatively, students can acquire an affordable health benefits plan sponsored by the University: the UNH Student Health Benefits Plan (SHBP). International students with F-1 and J-1 visas are required to purchase the SHBP. Learn more about the SHBP and the waiver process.

column2: How many credits can I take?
column3: Maximum Load The maximum graduate load allowed is 16 credits (12 credits for a student on a full assistantship). Only under unusual circumstances will a student be allowed to exceed these limits, and then only with the recommendation of the student’s adviser and graduate program coordinator and the approval of the dean of the Graduate School. Graduate students are charged full tuition plus the appropriate course charge for each credit beyond 16, if registered for more than 16 credits thirty days after the semester has begun. This applies to both courses taken for credit or audit. Tuition waivers awarded with assistantships and scholarships do not cover charges for tuition overload.
column4: ["- Registration Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/)"]

column2: What is the difference between GRAD 800 and GRAD 900?
column3: Continuing Enrollment (GRAD 800) (Part-Time Status, 0 Credits) Continuing graduate students who are not enrolled for course credits, thesis credits, Doctoral Research (999), or GRAD 900 Master’s Continuing Research, are not in residence, and are not exempt from the continuous enrollment policy, are required to register for GRAD 800 Continuing Enrollment each semester of the academic year (or each summer for students in M.S.T programs). The cost for this registration is $200. There are no additional fees. Students registered for GRAD 800 are considered part-time, 0 credits. New students are not eligible to enroll in GRAD 800. Master’s Continuing Research (Grad 900) (Full-time Status, 0 credits) Master’s Continuing Research (GRAD 900) is for Master’s students who are in residence and need to be full time but have already completed all course requirements, have previously registered for the maximum number of thesis or project credits. The cost for this registration is $500. As this grants full-time status, students are also responsible for the full time mandatory fees. Effective Fall 2020, GRAD 900 may be taken only once. However, students who need to repeat this registration may do so with permission.
column4: ["- Registration Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/)"]

column2: What is full time status?
column3: Full/Part Time Status Full-Time Students Graduate students registered for 9 or more credits, GRAD 900 Master’s Continuing Research, or Doctoral Research (999) are classified as full-time students. Students holding assistantship appointments are also considered full time and must register for a minimum of 6 credits, GRAD 900 Master’s Continuing Research, or Doctoral Research (999) each semester.
column4: ["- Registration Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/)"]

column2: What financial aid is available?
column3: Financial Assistance Several forms of financial assistance are available to graduate students through the Graduate School and individual departments, most of which are awarded for an academic year commencing in the fall. To be eligible for any assistance, the student must first be admitted to the Graduate School. In most cases, the application for admission with supporting documents serves as the application for new graduate students for the scholarship and assistantship programs available to them. In other cases, individual departments have their own application forms. Students are advised to contact individual programs for more information about assistantships and scholarships, and any departmental application forms.
column4: ["- Fees Financial Support Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/fees-financial-support/)"]

column2: Where can I find information about assistantships?
column3: Graduate Appointments 2025-2026 The university offers a variety of forms of financial assistance to graduate students in support of their efforts to obtain a graduate degree. Graduate appointments are made to post-baccalaureate students who have been regularly or provisionally admitted to the Graduate School and who have been recommended by the appropriate department or program and approved for appointment by the Graduate School. Appointments are normally for one academic year and may be renewed provided that funds are available and that the student’s academic performance, as well as performance in carrying out the responsibilities of the appointment, is satisfactory. Note: Some departments will divide graduate awards in half so as to support a greater number of applicants. Please contact the appropriate departmental graduate coordinator for more questions on graduate award amounts.
column4: ["- Fees Financial Support Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/fees-financial-support/)"]

column2: How do I withdraw from the program?
column3: Withdrawal A student may request to fully withdraw from their graduate degree program during any semester by obtaining a withdrawal form from the Graduate School website. Students who formally withdraw are required to apply for readmission if they subsequently desire to resume their academic program. Students who are applying for readmission are required to pay an application fee plus, if readmitted, any accumulated continuing enrollment fees for the period during which they have been inactive. Students are not guaranteed readmission and may be evaluated in competition with current applicants to the program.
column4: ["- Registration Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/)"]

column2: Can I change my degree?
column3: Change of Degree Students who wish to pursue a degree program other than the one for which admission was originally granted must complete the appropriate application for a change of degree. This includes students enrolled in UNH master’s programs who intend to pursue the Ph.D. in the same department in which they were admitted for the master’s degree. These forms are available at the Graduate School’s website. The dean of the Graduate School will notify the student of the decision after consulting with the appropriate departments.
column4: ["- Registration Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/)"]

column2: How long does it typically take to complete the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Full-time students can complete the program in 18 months. Students admitted from a UNH Bachelor’s degree program can complete the Accelerated Master’s program in 12 months depending on the courses completed during their undergraduate program. Students choosing the project or internship track would undertake an internship or internships in industry, applied research in an industrial job where the student is already employed, or research in a faculty member’s laboratory at UNH. Students choosing the co-op work experience route would spend 6 months in a full-time industrial placement as part of their degree program.
column4: ["- Biotechnology Industrial Biomedical Sciences Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/biotechnology/biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms/#requirementstext)"]

column2: How many total credits are required for the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.)?
column3: The M.S. in Biotech:IBMS is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and a Capstone experience (3-9 credits).
column4: ["- Biotechnology Industrial Biomedical Sciences Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/biotechnology/biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms/#requirementstext)"]

column2: How many credits are required in the Core Curriculum for the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The Core Curriculum requires 13 credits.
column4: ["- Biotechnology Industrial Biomedical Sciences Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/biotechnology/biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms/#requirementstext)"]

column2: How many elective credits are required in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Students complete between 8 and 14 elective credits.
column4: ["- Biotechnology Industrial Biomedical Sciences Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/biotechnology/biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms/#requirementstext)"]

column2: What is the credit range for the Capstone Experience in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The Capstone Experience requires between 3 and 9 credits.
column4: ["- Biotechnology Industrial Biomedical Sciences Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/biotechnology/biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms/#requirementstext)"]

column2: When can students in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program begin their capstone experience?
column3: After completion of 9 credits in the MS Biotechnology program, students are required to enroll in at least one credit under Capstone Experience: BIOT 891, BIOT 892, BIOT 895, or BIOT 889. The capstone (up to 9 credits) will be designed and approved by your faculty advisor or the internship and co-op coordinator and will be consistent with your career development plans.
column4: ["- Biotechnology Industrial Biomedical Sciences Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/biotechnology/biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms/#requirementstext)"]

column2: What is the purpose of the Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The MS Biotech:IBMS core curriculum is centered around research project team-based lab courses. This provides you with important industry-relevant transferrable job skills, such as clear communication, cooperation and relationship building, teamwork and conflict resolution, and creative problem-solving and strategic thinking. These transferrable skills are developed hand-in-hand with the wet-lab skills. In addition to the core lab and lecture coursework covering the major industry areas of cell, molecular, and protein biochemistry, the program incorporates a core course entitled “Biotechnology Products and Regulation.” This course takes a critical look at industry from the initial stages of research and development in the biomedical sciences through the legal and regulatory stages of biotechnology product development and manufacturing. This content is key to understanding how the biotech industry functions and thus is a centerpiece in your training in our degree program. Finally, you are required to enroll in a minimum of one graduate biotech seminar course. While the specific content of the seminar courses will vary to reflect the dynamics of the ever-changing biotech field, the two typical focus areas of the semester-long seminars will be “Instrumentation in the Biotech Industry” and “Cutting edge topics in the Biotech Industry today”.
column4: ["- Biotechnology Industrial Biomedical Sciences Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/biotechnology/biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms/#requirementstext)"]

column2: Who helps Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) students develop a curriculum plan?
column3: You will develop a curriculum plan with your Faculty Advisor that includes elective courses. This curriculum plan will be customized to meet your career goals.

column2: What is the main academic focus of the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Biotechnology focuses on the application of the biological and biochemical sciences, and particularly genetics, to the preparation of new and enhanced biomedical, industrial, agricultural, and environmental products. Graduate instruction in this area would include molecular biology, cell and tissue culturing, protein biologic development, bioinformatics, functional and comparative genomics, applied immunology, DNA sequencing, tissue biology and engineering, industrial microbiology, drug development, intellectual property, clinical trials, biotechnology management and marketing, applicable regulations, and biotechnology ethics.
column4: ["- Biotechnology Industrial Biomedical Sciences Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/biotechnology/biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms/#requirementstext)"]

column2: Does the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program integrate academic and professional preparation?
column3: Yes. The curriculum integrates academic coursework with professional skill development through the capstone.

column3: Core courses build foundational knowledge, while electives allow students to apply and expand that knowledge.

column3: Accelerated Master’s programs offer qualified University of New Hampshire undergraduate students the opportunity to begin graduate coursework in select graduate programs while completing a bachelor’s degree.

column2: What is the overall purpose of the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) Accelerated Master’s Option?
column3: It bridges undergraduate and graduate study, providing an efficient pathway to advanced biotechnology training and career preparation.
column4: ["- Biotechnology Industrial Biomedical Sciences Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/biotechnology/biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms/#acceleratedmasterstext)"]

column2: What core knowledge areas will students master in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The MS Biotech:IBMS program has a core foundation in the theory and wet-laboratory skills of cell and tissue biology and culturing; protein and immunologic methods and therapeutics; and the molecular biotechnology of nucleic acids.

column2: What laboratory skills will students develop in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Students gain high-level lab skills in mammalian cell culture, molecular biology, microbiology, and protein techniques.
column4: ["- Biotechnology Industrial Biomedical Sciences Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/biotechnology/biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms/#studentlearningoutcomestext)"]

column2: What legal and regulatory understanding is expected in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Successfully employ knowledge of the regulatory and legal framework that underpins the field of industrial biotechnology, including knowledge of pre-clinical and clinical product development, relevant US government regulations and laws, and intellectual property concerns.
column4: ["- Biotechnology Industrial Biomedical Sciences Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/biotechnology/biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms/#studentlearningoutcomestext)"]

column2: How will students communicate technical information in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Students will be able to demonstrate the ability to communicate high-level technical information related to biotechnology in scientific writing and oral presentations to a variety of audiences.
column4: ["- Biotechnology Industrial Biomedical Sciences Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/biotechnology/biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms/#studentlearningoutcomestext)"]

column2: How do students engage with research literature in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: They learn to understand, analyze, evaluate, and summarize primary research literature involving biotechnology related topics.
column4: ["- Biotechnology Industrial Biomedical Sciences Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/biotechnology/biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms/#studentlearningoutcomestext)"]

column2: How is the scientific method applied in the biotechnology: industrial and biomedical sciences (m.s.) program?
column3: Students will be able to understand and apply the process of the scientific method, including being able to formulate hypotheses, design and conduct experiments with adequate controls to test hypotheses, interpret and evaluate data, and draw conclusions.
column4: ["- Biotechnology Industrial Biomedical Sciences Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/biotechnology/biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms/#studentlearningoutcomestext)"]

column2: What quantitative and data skills are emphasized in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Biotechnology focuses on the application of the biological and biochemical sciences, and particularly genetics, to the preparation of new and enhanced biomedical, industrial, agricultural, and environmental products. Graduate instruction in this area would include molecular biology, cell and tissue culturing, protein biologic development, bioinformatics, functional and comparative genomics, applied immunology, DNA sequencing, tissue biology and engineering, industrial microbiology, drug development, intellectual property, clinical trials, biotechnology management and marketing, applicable regulations, and biotechnology ethics.
column4: ["- Biotechnology Industrial Biomedical Sciences Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/biotechnology/biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms/#requirementstext)"]

column2: What transferable professional skills are emphasized in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Students will able to deploy important biotechnology industry-relevant transferrable job skills, such as clear communication, cooperation and relationship building, teamwork and conflict resolution, and creative problem-solving and strategic thinking.
column4: ["- Biotechnology Industrial Biomedical Sciences Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/biotechnology/biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms/#studentlearningoutcomestext)"]

column3: Biotechnology focuses on the application of the biological and biochemical sciences, and particularly genetics, to the preparation of new and enhanced biomedical, industrial, agricultural, and environmental products.

column2: Who is the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) program designed for?
column3: It is designed for working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. You will learn the theoretical underpinnings of information security and have opportunities to apply your knowledge and skills to real-world scenarios and authentic project experiences.

column2: What completion options are listed on the Information Technology (M.S.) requirements page?
column3:
The M.S. in Information Technology program has two options for completion:

Master’s Project Option: 30 credits course work and 3 credits Master’s Project course (total of 33 credits)
Master’s Thesis Option: 24 credits coursework and 6 credits Master’s Thesis course (total of 30 credits)
Both options require completion of 18 core credits.

column2: What are the total credit combinations for the project and thesis options in the Information Technology (M.S.) program?

column2: How is the Master’s Thesis Option structured in the Information Technology (M.S.) program?
column3: Master’s Thesis Option: 24 credits coursework and 6 credits Master’s Thesis course (total of 30 credits)
column4: ["- Information Technology Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/computing/information-technology-ms/#requirementstext)"]

column2: Who supervises the Master’s Thesis in the Information Technology (M.S.) program?
column3: The thesis is supervised by a faculty member.
column4: ["- Information Technology Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/computing/information-technology-ms/#requirementstext)"]

column2: Does the Information Technology (M.S.) curriculum include both coursework and research?
column3: Yes. Students complete coursework and may engage in research through the thesis or project option.
column4: ["- Information Technology Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/computing/information-technology-ms/#requirementstext)"]

column2: Is there a specific credit requirement for the internship course in the Information Technology (M.S.) program?
column3: Yes. Students must take at least 1 credit of the Internship Experience course.
column4: ["- Information Technology Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/computing/information-technology-ms/#requirementstext)"]

column2: Does the Information Technology (M.S.) program require a final presentation or report?
column3: Yes. Students complete a final presentation or report as part of the thesis or project option.
column4: ["- Information Technology Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/computing/information-technology-ms/#requirementstext)"]

column2: What is the total number of credits required to complete the Master’s Project Option in the Information Technology (M.S.) program
column3: Master’s Project Option: 30 credits course work and 3 credits Master’s Project course (total of 33 credits)
column4: ["- Information Technology Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/computing/information-technology-ms/#requirementstext)"]

column2: What is the total number of credits required to complete the Master’s Thesis Option in the Information Technology (M.S.) program?
column3: Master’s Thesis Option: 24 credits coursework and 6 credits Master’s Thesis course (total of 30 credits)
column4: ["- Information Technology Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/computing/information-technology-ms/#requirementstext)"]

column2: What is the total number of graduate credits needed to complete any option in the Information Technology (M.S.) program?
column3: A minimum of 30 graduate credits is required to complete either option.
column4: ["- Information Technology Ms Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/computing/information-technology-ms/#requirementstext)"]

column2: What is the minimum GPA to apply to the Accelerated Master’s program?
column3: A minimum cumulative GPA of 3.2 is normally required to apply to the Accelerated Master’s program (some departments may set higher requirements).
column4: ["- Accelerated Masters Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/undergraduate/academic-policies-procedures/accelerated-masters/)"]

column2: Can I take 900-level courses as an Accelerated Master’s student for dual credit?
column3: No. Accelerated Master’s students may only take 800-level courses for dual credit.
column4: ["- Accelerated Masters Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/undergraduate/academic-policies-procedures/accelerated-masters/)"]

column2: How many credits can I take for dual credit in the Accelerated Master’s program?
column3: Up to 12 credits for dual credit in most programs; some programs have stricter limits.
column4: ["- Accelerated Masters Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/undergraduate/academic-policies-procedures/accelerated-masters/)"]

column2: What is the minimum grade I must earn in dual-credit courses for the Accelerated Master’s?
column3: B- or better is required for dual-credit courses.
column4: ["- Accelerated Masters Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/undergraduate/academic-policies-procedures/accelerated-masters/)"]

column2: Do I need to be admitted to the Accelerated Master’s program to take 800-level courses for dual credit?
column3: Yes. You must be admitted to the Accelerated Master’s program to take 800-level courses for dual credit.
column4: ["- Accelerated Masters Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/undergraduate/academic-policies-procedures/accelerated-masters/)"]

column2: Do all programs at UNH offer an Accelerated Master’s option?
column3: No. Not all programs have an Accelerated Master’s option; check the Graduate Catalog program pages for participating programs.
column4: ["- Accelerated Masters Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/programs/#filter=.filter_24&view=list)"]

column2: What’s the difference between IA and IC grades for graduate students?
column3: IC is assigned, with instructor approval, for excused unfinished work and must be completed by the stated deadline. IA indicates an Incomplete in continuing multi-semester work (e.g., thesis/doctoral research); earlier IA terms remain on the transcript, and only the final completed term receives CR when applicable.
column4: ["- Grading Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)"]

column2: Can I appeal a course grade?
column3: Yes. After discussing the evaluation with the instructor, students may seek redress with the department/program chair. In exceptional cases, a final appeal may be made to the dean of the college or school.
column4: ["- Grading Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)"]

column2: What registration is required for graduate assistants to be considered full time?
column3: Graduate assistants must register each semester for a minimum of 6 credits, GRAD 900 (Master’s Continuing Research), or Doctoral Research (999).
column4: ["- Registration Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/fees-financial-support/)"]

column2: How many courses can I take during January Term (J-Term)?
column3: J-Term is a three-week winter session with online, on-campus, and study-away courses. Because it’s intensive, students may register for only one course during J-Term.
column4: ["- Registration Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/)"]

column2: How is a master’s thesis committee formed at UNH?
column3: A master’s thesis is approved by a committee consisting of the thesis adviser (a regular member of the graduate faculty) and two additional graduate faculty members nominated by the department chair or graduate program coordinator and appointed by the dean of the Graduate School. Non-graduate-faculty members may serve per program policy.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#text)"]

column2: When is the deadline to apply for Fall 2025?
column3: Application deadlines vary by graduate program. Most programs begin reviewing Fall 2025 applications in December or January. Applicants should check their specific program page for exact deadlines and priority consideration dates.
column4: ["- Admissions Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/admissions/)"]

column2: How do I apply for a graduate certificate?
column3: To apply for a graduate certificate program, applicants must complete the Graduate School online application, select the specific certificate program, and submit official transcripts. Some programs may require letters of recommendation or additional materials.
column4: ["- Admissions Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/admissions/)"]

column2: Can I defer my admission offer?
column3: Applicants who are admitted but unable to enroll may request to defer admission for up to one year. Requests must be submitted in writing and are considered only once. Approved deferrals do not permit enrollment in graduate coursework during the deferral period.
column4: ["- Admissions Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/admissions/)"]

column2: How many years do I have to finish my master’s?
column3: All requirements for a master’s degree must normally be completed within four years of matriculation. Extensions may be granted on a case-by-case basis, and approved leaves of absence do not count toward the time limit.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: Where can I find information about graduate housing?
column3: Graduate housing information is available through UNH Housing. Babcock Hall provides housing for students age 21 and older, including graduate and international students. Details are listed on the UNH Housing website under Graduate Housing.
column4: ["- Campus Life Information (https://www.unh.edu/housing/housing-options/graduate-housing)"]

column2: How do I submit my thesis?
column3: The final approved thesis must be submitted electronically via the UNH ETD Administrator (ProQuest) website by the published deadline. Students may order bound copies through ProQuest and pay all associated submission and copyright fees at the time of submission.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: What are the mandatory fees for graduate assistants?
column3: Mandatory Fees: Students holding full-time assistantships are charged 50% of the full-time mandatory fees rate. Students appointed as assistants, fellows and lecturers receive a fee waiver for the technology fee during the period of their appointment. Course fees are also covered by the waiver. Mandatory fees are not covered by waivers, although scholarships may be awarded to individual students to cover these fees.
column4: ["- Fees Financial Support Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/fees-financial-support/)"]

column2: How much are graduate assistants paid?
column3:
Stipends:
- Level 1 - $22,890 (All masters’ students and doctoral students with a bachelor’s degree who have less than 2 years of experience as a GA or RA at UNH)
- Level 2 - - $24,010 (Doctoral students with a master’s degree or doctoral students with a bachelor’s degree who have 2 years of experience as a GA or RA @ UNH)
- Level 3 - - $25,310 (Doctoral students at candidacy)
column4: ["- Fees Financial Support Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/fees-financial-support/)"]

column2: How do I apply for financial aid or scholarships?
column3: Graduate students apply for assistantships and scholarships through their academic department or graduate program. Admission materials often serve as the application for funding. Students seeking federal aid must complete the FAFSA.
column4: ["- Fees Financial Support Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/fees-financial-support/)"]

column2: How do I withdraw from a graduate program?
column3: Students may withdraw from their graduate program by submitting a withdrawal form to the Graduate School. Readmission requires a new application, fee, and payment of any continuing enrollment fees for inactive periods.
column4: ["- Registration Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/)"]

column2: Can I take undergraduate courses as a grad student?
column3: Graduate students may petition to earn graduate credit for up to 12 credits of 700-level undergraduate courses outside their program. The courses must be taken for a letter grade and approved by the adviser, program coordinator, and Graduate School.
column4: ["- Courses Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/courses/)"]

column2: What is the time limit for a Ph.D.?
column3: Ph.D. students must complete the degree within eight years of matriculation, or seven years if entering with a master’s degree in the same field. Advancement to candidacy must occur within five years (four with a prior master’s).
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: What is a non-terminal master’s degree?
column3: Ph.D. students may petition to earn a non-terminal master’s degree while completing their doctoral program. They must complete all requirements for the master’s degree in their field and submit the petition at the start of the intended graduation semester.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: How do I file an intent to graduate?
column3: All students MUST file an intent-­to-­graduate through Webcat by the appropriate deadline specified on the UNH Academic Calendar. Students who do not file an intent-to-graduate will not have their degree awarded. More information on this process is available on the Graduate School’s website.
column4: ["- Graduation Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/)"]

column2: What is the process for appealing an academic dismissal?
column3: To appeal a dismissal decision, a student must submit a letter and any supporting documents to the program chairperson and the dean of the Graduate School within ten (10) business days of the dismissal notification. The appeal should provide specific evidence, context, or mitigating factors that the student believes should be considered in reviewing the decision.
column4: ["- Academic Standards Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/)"]

column2: How many transfer credits can be applied to a graduate degree?
column3: A maximum of 12 credits taken prior to matriculation (internal and external combined) may be applied toward a degree program. Transfer credits must be approved and appear on the UNH transcript to count toward degree requirements.
column4: ["- Credit Transfer Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/credit-transfer/)"]

column2: Can I take a leave of absence?
column3: Students may request a leave of absence for up to one year due to extenuating circumstances such as medical, military, or family reasons. Requests must include documentation and be approved by the dean of the Graduate School upon recommendation of the adviser and program coordinator.
column4: ["- Registration Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/)"]

column2: What is RCR training?
column3: Responsible Conduct of Research (RCR) training is required for all incoming Ph.D. students by the end of their first semester. The training teaches ethical and responsible research practices and is approved by the Graduate School.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: What is a guidance committee?
column3: A guidance committee is appointed by program faculty early in the Ph.D. program to assist students in planning coursework, preparing for qualifying exams, and overseeing academic progress.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: What is the minimum passing grade for graduate students?
column3: Graduate credit is granted only for courses completed with a grade of B- or higher. Individual programs may set stricter standards published in their program requirements.
column4: ["- Academic Standards Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/)"]

column2: Can I take a course Pass/Fail?
column3: Graduate courses cannot be taken pass/fail. A graduate student may petition to take undergraduate courses on a pass/fail basis, but 700-level courses approved for graduate credit cannot be taken pass/fail.
column4: ["- Grading Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)"]

column2: How do I change my degree?
column3: Students who wish to change to a different degree program must complete the Change of Degree application available on the Graduate School website. The request is reviewed by the dean after consultation with the appropriate departments.
column4: ["- Registration Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/)"]

column2: What GPA is required to graduate?
column3: Graduate students MUST have a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher in order to graduate.
column4: ["- Academic Standards Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/)"]

column2: Can I appeal a grade?
column3: Appeals: Every instructor must be prepared to discuss and explain the basis for their evaluation of students. If, after consulting the instructor, a student still believes that he or she was treated unfairly, he or she has the right to seek redress from the chairperson of the department or program in which the course is offered. Under exceptional circumstances, a final appeal may be made to the dean of the college or school in which the program is offered.
column4: ["- Grading Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)"]

column2: Can I enroll in more than one degree?
column3: Dual Degrees: Graduate School allows UNH students to pursue two degrees at UNH and count credits toward both degrees under the circumstances detailed below.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#text)"]

column2: What is the registration requirement for graduate assistants?
column3: Assistants, fellows or graduate part-time lecturers must register for a minimum of 6 course/thesis credits, Master's Continuing Research (GRAD 900)or Doctoral Research (999) during each semester in which they hold their appointments.
column4: ["- Fees Financial Support Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/fees-financial-support/)"]

column2: What is JTerm?
column3: January Term is a three-week learning opportunity held during winter break. Online, on-campus, and study-away credit courses are available in a variety of academic disciplines at both the undergraduate and graduate levels. Because of the intensive course of study, students may register for only one course during January Term. For more information, visit https://unh.edu/januaryterm/.
column4: ["- Registration Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/)"]

column2: What is GRAD 800?
column3: Continuing graduate students who are not enrolled for course credits, thesis credits, Doctoral Research (999), or GRAD 900 Master's Continuing Research, are not in residence, and are not exempt from the continuous enrollment policy, are required to register for GRAD 800 Continuing Enrollment each semester of the academic year (or each summer for students in M.S.T programs).
column4: ["- Registration Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/)"]

column2: What is GRAD 900?
column3: Master's Continuing Research (GRAD 900) is for Master's students who are in residence and need to be full time but have already completed all course requirements, have previously registered for the maximum number of thesis or project credits. The cost for this registration is $500. As this grants full-time status, students are also responsible for the full time mandatory fees. Effective Fall 2020, GRAD 900 may be taken only once. However, students who need to repeat this registration may do so with permission.
column4: ["- Registration Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/)"]

column2: How do I sibmity my committee?
column3: A master's thesis must be approved by a committee composed of a regular member of the graduate faculty under whose direction it was written and two other members of the graduate faculty nominated by the department chairperson or graduate program coordinator and appointed by the dean of the Graduate School. Individuals who are not regular members of the graduate faculty may be nominated to serve on committees in accordance with individual program policies.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#text)"]

column2: What is the difference between an IA and an IC grade?
column3: An "IC" grade is assigned with the approval of the instructor for excused unfinished work only. "IA" indicates "incomplete" in thesis credit, doctoral research, or other continuing courses of more than one semester.
column4: ["- Grading Information (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)"]
